meta.name: generator
meta.content: HTML Tidy for Windows (vers 14 February 2006), see www.w3.org

div.p: Plugin Version @PLUGIN_VERSION@

IBM WebSphere Application Server (WAS), a software application server, is the flagship product in IBM WebSphere brand. It provides the flexibility, efficiency, and intelligent management required by an agile, cost-effective business.

For more information about WebSphere, go to the WebSphere
Home Page.

You use this plugin to interact with an IBM WebSphere Server. You can start and stop the server.
You can also manage applications within the server (start, deploy, undeploy, stop or custom task) using the provided WebSphere scripts in the bin directory under the installation home directory (wsadmin, startServer, stopServer). You can run Jython scripts that are provided by the user or defined when a procedure is created.
The plugin was developed and tested against WebSphere Network Deployment Version 8.5.
IMPORTANT: For all the following parameter descriptions, the required parameters are in bold italics.

Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin procedures. They
reduce repetition of common values, create predefined parameter sets for end users, and securely store credentials where needed. Each configuration is given a unique name that is entered in designated parameters on procedures that use them.

To create plugin configurations in ElectricCommander,
do these steps:

ol.li: Go to Administration > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.

Click Configure to open the
WebSphere Configurations page.

To enable Commander to communicate with your WebSphere Application Server,
enter the following information:

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to create.
WebSphere Host
The URL of the WebSphere Server.
WebSphere Admin Port

The port for the WebSphere administrative console. This port is used with the WebSphere URL. If it is not specified, ElectricCommander uses 9043 as the default port. For example, you can specify 9070 as the port.
Login as

Username: The user name used by ElectricCommander to communicate with the WebSphere server.
Password: The password for the Username.
Retype Password: Re-enter the password.

div.p: The WebSphere Configurations page now shows the new configuration.

To edit plugin configurations in ElectricCommander,
do these steps:

ol.li: Go to Administration > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.

Click Configure to open the
WebSphere Configurations page.
Find the configuration that you want to edit.
Edit the parameters in the configuration.
Click OK to save the modified configuration.

div.p: This procedure checks if a web application is ready by using a Jython script.

tr.td: Application Name
The name of the web application to check, such as webapp.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension.
Examples: /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.

div.p: This procedure checks the status of the page with the specified URL.

tr.td: Credentials to be entered (also referred to as credentialName in the property view)
The credentials required to check the status of the page. You must enter a Username and Password.
Target URL (also referred to as targeturl in the property view)
The URL of the page to check.
Maximum Elapsed Time (also referred to as maxelapsedtime in the property view)
The maximum time in seconds that the job tries to check into the server. When the text box is blank, ElectricCommander interprets this as no wait time and checks the URL only one time.
Success Criteria (also referred to as successcriteria in the property view)
The expected result when the page is checked.

div.h3: Checking the Status of a Page
div.p: To check the status of page at a specific URL, do the following steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details,
which show that the criteria was reached:

In the CheckPageStatus step, click the Log
icon to see the diagnostic info. The output is similar
to the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure checks the status of the specified server URL.

tr.td: Configuration Name
Name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Maximum Elapsed Time
The maximum time in seconds that the job tries to check into the server. When the text box is blank, ElectricCommander interprets this as no wait time and checks the URL only one time.
Success Criteria
The expected result to be obtained when WebSphere server is checked.

div.p: The procedure creates a datasource by using a Jython script.

tr.td: Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the PATH environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples of paths are /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
JDBC Provider
The name of an existing JDBC Provider.
Datasource Name
The name of the datasource that is unique in the WebSphere domain.
Datasource Description
A description of the datasource.
JNDI Name
The JNDI path to which this datasource is bound.
Statement Cache Size
The number of statements that can be cached per connection. The application server caches a statement after that statement is closed.
Authentication Alias Name
The authentication data alias.
Datasource Helper Class Name
The datasource helper class name.
Connection Type
The type of connection to use when connecting to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE.

div.p: To create a datasource, do the following steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details,
which show that the datasource was successfully created:

In the CreateDatasource step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure creates a JDBC provider using a Jython script.

tr.td: Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the wsadmin tool that includes filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the PATH environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples are /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
JDBC Provider Name
The name of the JDBC Provider.
JDBC Provider Description
A description for the JDBC Provider.
Cell Scope

The parent object where the JDBC Provider will be created. This determines the visibility scope of the JDBC Provider. If the Cell Scope is specified and the node and server scopes are not specified, the scope will be the Cell. If the node is specified and the server is not, the scope will be the Node. If the server is specified and the node is not, the scope will be the Server. You must specify the Cell, Node, or Server scope must be provided, such as wsaspluginNode01Cell.
Node Scope

If the Node Scope is specified and the cell and server scopes are not, the scope will be the node. If the Cell Scope is provided and the server is not, the scope will be the node. If the server is provided and the cell is not, the scope will be the server. An example is wsaspluginNode01.
Server Scope
When the Server Scope is provided, the scope will always be node and the server, even if the Node Scope and the Cell Scope are not specified. An example is server1.
Implementation Class Name
Java class name of the JDBC provider implementation.
Driver Class Path
A path for the resource provider classes.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE.

div.p: To create a JDBC provider, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details,
which show that JDBC provider was successfully created:

In the CreateJDBCProvider step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.

Datasource Name
The name of the datasource that is unique in the WebSphere domain.
Connection Type

This procedure deletes a JDBC provider using a Jython script.

tr.td: Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the PATH environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted, such as /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
JDBC Provider Name
The name of the JDBC Provider that is unique in the WebSphere domain.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE.

This procedure deploys an application using a Jython script that invokes AdminApp.install for the deployment process.

tr.td: Commands
Commands to enter in the wsadmin tool. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
Java options to to pass to wsadmin. Separate them with semicolons (;).
Classpath

The JAR files to pass to the wsadmin classpath. This is a string containing the paths (separated by semicolons) to the required JAR files that execute wsadmin in a particular job. Examples are c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar and /MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the wsadmin tool that include the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored in is the path environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples are /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Application Name
The name of the web application to deploy, such as webapp.
Application Path
The absolute path of the application, such as /path/to/webapp.war or c:/mydir/webapp.war.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands enter in the wsadmin tool.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. The default is SOAP.

div.p: To deploy an application, do these steps:select the following highlighted step:
After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that the application was deployed successfully:
In the DeployApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report.
This procedure runs a task using wsadmin and the Jython code files.

tr.td: Commands
The commands to enter in the wsadmin tool. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
The Java options to pass to wsadmin. Separate them with semicolons (;).
Classpath

The JAR files to pass to the wsadmin classpath. This is a string containing paths (separated by semicolons) to the required JAR files that execute wsadmin in a particular job. Examples are c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar and /MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path to the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the path environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples are /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Script File Absolute Path

The path of a Jython script that will be run using wsadmin. This path is used only when the Supplied File option in the Script File Source parameter is selected. Examples are /path/to/scriptFile.jython and c:/dir/scriptFile.jython.
Script File Source
The source is a script file route (Supplied File) or an embedded script file (New Script File).
Script File

The content of the script file when the New Script File is selected for the Script File Source. This parameter is used only when the New Script File option in the Script File Source
is selected.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter in the wsadmin tool.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. The default is SOAP.

div.p: For a complete example, go to the Examples and Use Cases section.
This procedure starts an application using wsadmin.

tr.td: Commands
The commands to enter in the wsadmin tool. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
The Java options to pass to wsadmin. Separate them with semicolons (;).
Classpath

The JAR files to pass to the wsadmin classpath. It is a string containing paths (semicolon-separated) to the required JAR files that execute wsadmin in a particular job. Examples are c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar and /MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path to the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the path environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples are /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Application Name

The name of the application to start, such as
webapp.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered in the wsadmin tool.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. The default is SOAP.

div.p: To start an application, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details,
which show that application was started successfully:
In the StartApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report.
This procedure starts a WebSphere instance.

tr.td: Instance Name

The name of the instance of the server
to start, such as server01.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of the StartServer script that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the PATH environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted. Examples are startServer.bat, /path/to/startServer.sh, and C:\Program Files\IBM\WebSphere\AppServer\bin\startServer.bat.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter when the server starts.

div.p: This procedure stops an application using wsadmin.

tr.td: Commands
The commands to enter in the wsadmin tool. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
The Java options to pass to the wsadmin tool. Separate them with semicolons (;).
Classpath

The JAR files to be passed to the wsadmin classpath. This is a string containing paths (separated by semicolons) to the required JAR files that execute wsadmin in a particular job. Examples are c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar and /MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path of wsadmin that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the path environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted, such as /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Application Name
The name of the application to stop, such as webapp.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommmander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter in the wsadmin tool.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. The default is SOAP.

div.p: To stop an application, do these steps:
After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that the application was stoped successfully:
In the StopApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report.
This procedure stops a WebSphere instance.

tr.td: Script Location
The absolute path to the start server script. Leave this blank when the script is loaded in the system path.
Instance Name
The name of the server instance to stop, such as server01.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter to stop the server.

div.p: This procedure undeploys an application using a Jython script and invoking AdminApp.uninstall.

tr.td: Commands
The commands to enter in the wsadmin tool. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
The Java options to pass to the wsadmin tool. Separate them with semicolons (;).
Classpath

The JAR files to pass to the wsadmin classpath. This is a string containing paths (separated by semicolons) to the required JAR files that execute wsadmin in a specific job. Examples are c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar and /MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar.
Wsadmin Absolute Path

The absolute path to the wsadmin tool that includes the filename and extension. If the path in which wsadmin is stored is in the PATH environmental variable, the absolute path is omitted, such as /path/to/wsadmin.sh and wsadmin.bat.
Application Name
The name of the application, such as webapp.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to enter in the wsadmin tool.
Connection Type
The type of connection used to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid options are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.

div.p: To undeploy an application, do these steps:
After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that the application was undeployed successfully:
In the UndeployApp step, click the Log icon to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to the following diagnostic report.
This procedure creates a new cluster, adds members to it and optionally deploys an application on it using a Jython script.

tr.td: Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Cell name
Name of the cell in which to create a new cluster.
Cluster Name
Name of the new cluster.
Cluster Members
List of member app servers along with node names.For eg. if server1 and server2 on Node01 and Node02 resp. have to be members give input as Node01=server1,Node02=server2
Deploy Application on new cluster?
Select the checkbox if you want to deploy an app on new cluster.
Commands
Commands to be entered to wsadmin. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
Java options to be passed to wsadmin, separate them using semicolons (;).
Classpath

Jars to be passed to the wsadmin classpath. It is a string containing paths (semicolon-separated) the required JARs to execute wsadmin in a particular job. i.e: 'c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar' or '/MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar'
Application Name
Name of the web application to be deploy. i.e: 'webapp'.
Application Path
Absolute path of the application to deploy. i.e: '/path/to/webapp.war' or 'c:/mydir/webapp.war'.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered for wsadmin.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.

div.p: To create new cluster, add application servers as its members and deploy an application on it, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
the cluster was created successfully:

In the CreateCluster step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure lists down all the members (application servers) of the cluster using a Jython script.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Cluster Name
Name of the cluster of which members to list down.

div.p: To list all the members of the cluster, do these steps:

members of the cluster are listed successfully:

In the ListClusterMembers step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure removes specified application servers from the cluster using a Jython script.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Cluster Name
Name of cluster from which to remove/delete the members.
List of cluster members
List of cluster members in the form Node01=server1,Node02=server2,... to remove/delete from cluster.

div.p: To remove the members from application server cluster, do these steps:

This procedure deletes specified cluster using a Jython script.

tr.td: Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Cluster Name
The name of the cluster to delete.

div.p: To delete application server cluster, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
cluster is deleted successfully:

In the DeleteCluster step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure configures EJB container properites using a Jython script.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Cell Name
Name of cell to which EJB container belongs to.
Node Name
Name of node to which EJB container belongs to. .
Server Name
Name of application server to which EJB container belongs to.
Passivation Directory

Specifies the directory into which the container saves the persistent state of passivated stateful session beans. This directory must already exist. It is not automatically created.Default is ${USER_INSTALL_ROOT}/temp.
cache Size

Number of buckets in the active instance list within the EJB container.Input value range - greater than 0. The container selects the next largest prime number equal to or greater than the specified value.Default is 2053
Cleanup Interval
Interval (in milliseconds)at which the container attempts to remove unused items from the cache.Default is 3000. Allowed range is 0 to 2147483647
Inactive Pool Cleanup Interval
Specifies the interval at which the container examines the pools of available bean instances to determine if some instances can be deleted to reduce memory usage.
Enable stateful session bean fail over using memory-to-memory replication?
Specifies that failover is enabled for all stateful session beans installed in this EJB container.Replication domains must already exist to failover feature to work.
Replication domain
Specifies the replication domain in which HTTP sessions are replicated.
Replication Mode

The mode specifies whether data is only sent (client), only received (server), or both. Select client if sessions need to be replicated. Select server if sessions need to be stored. Select both client and server if sessions need to be replicated and stored. The default is both.

div.p: To Configure EJB Container, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
ejb container is configured successfully:

In the ConfigEJBContainer step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure creates a new JMS provider using a Jython script.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Scope
Specifies a scope of cell, node, server, or cluster for the JMS provider. E.g. Cell=Cell01,Node=Node01,Server=server1
JMS Provider Name
Specifies the name to assign to the new JMS provider.
Initial Context Factory
Specifies the Java class name of the initial context factory for the JMS provider.
JMS provider URL
Specifies the JMS provider URL for external JNDI lookups.
Classpath
>Specifies a list of paths or Java archive (JAR) file names which together form the location for the resource provider classes. Use a semicolon (;) to separate class paths.
Description
Specifies a description of the JMS Provider.
Isolated Class Loader
If set to true, specifies that the resource provider is loaded in its own class loader.
Native Path
Specifies an optional path to any native libraries, such as *.dll and *.so. Native path entries are separated by a semicolon (;).
Provider Type
Specifies the JMS provider type that this JMS provider uses.
Property Set
Specifies resource properties in the following format: [[['name','nameValue1'],['type','typeValue1'],['value','valueValue1']]... [['name','nameValuen'],['type','typeValuen'],['value','valueValuen']]]
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.

div.p: To create a new JMS provider, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
JMS provider is created successfully:

In the CreateJMSProvider step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure creates a JavaMail session object for default mail provider at specified scope.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Scope
Specifies the scope in which the mail session supports installed mail applications.For e.g. /Cell:Cell01/ServerCluster:testCluster/
Mail Session Name
Specifies the administrative name of the JavaMail session object.
Mail Session Description
Specifies optional description for mail session.
Mail Session JNDI Name
Specifies the Java Naming and Directory Interface (JNDI) name for the resource, including any naming subcontexts.
Category
Optional string to use while classifying or grouping the resources.
Enable Debug Mode?
>Select to print the interaction between mail application and mail server as well as the properties of this mail session to System.Out.log file.
Outgoing Mail Server
Specifies the host name of server that is accessed when sending mail.
Outgoing Mail Server Port
Specifies the port of the server that is accessed when sending mail.
Outgoing Mail Server Protocol
Specifies the protocol to use when sending mail.Valid values are SMTP and SMTP SSL
Outgoing Mail Server Credential
Specifies the user of the mail account when the outgoing mail server requires authentication.
Return E-mail Address
Represents the Internet email address that, by default, displays in the received message in the From or the Reply-To address. The recipient's reply will come to this address.
Incoming Mail Server
Specifies the host name server that is accessed when receiving mail.
Incoming Mail Server Port
Specifies the port of the server that is accessed when receiving mail.
Incoming Mail Server Protocol
Specifies the protocol to use when receiving mail.Valid values are IMAP, IMAP SSL, POP3, POP3 SSL.
Incoming Mail Server Credentials
Specifies the credential for the mail account when the incoming mail server requires authentication.
Enable Strict Internet Address Parsing?
Specifies whether the recipient addresses must be parsed in strict compliance with RFC 822.

div.p: To create a mail session for default mail provider, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
mail session is created successfully:

In the CreateMailSession step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure deploys and starts java enterprise application (.EAR) on given targets.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Commands
Commands to be entered to wsadmin. Use one command per line.
Classpath

Jars to be passed to the wsadmin classpath. It is a string containing paths (semicolon-separated) the required JARs to execute wsadmin in a particular job. i.e: 'c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar' or '/MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar'
Java Parameters
Java options to be passed to wsadmin, separate them using semicolons (;).
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered for wsadmin.
Application Name
Specifies logical name to be given to installing enterprise application. Do not include whitespaces in application name.
Application Path
Absolute path of the application to deploy. i.e: '/path/to/webapp.war' or 'c:/mydir/webapp.war'.
Target cluster list

Specify comma separated list of clusters on which to deploy enterprise application.Modules contained in an application can be installed on the same deployment target or dispersed among several deployment targets.
Target server list

Specify comma separated list of standalone servers on which to deploy enterprise application.Modules contained in an application can be installed on the same deployment target or dispersed among several deployment targets.Specify servers in the form Node=server. For e.g. Node01=Server1,Node02=Server2
Precompile JavaServer Pages files?
Specify whether to precompile JavaServer Pages (JSP) files as a part of installation. The default is not to precompile JSP files.
Directory to install application
Specifies the directory to which the enterprise archive (EAR) file will be installed.Default is profile_root/installedApps/cell_name/application_name.ear directory
Distribute application?
Specifies whether the product expands application binaries in the installation location during installation.
Use binary configuration

Specifies whether the application server uses the binding, extensions, and deployment descriptors located with the application deployment document, the deployment.xml file (default), or those located in the enterprise archive (EAR) file. Default is to use bindings located in deployment.xml.
Create MBeans for resources?
Specifies whether to create MBeans for resources such as servlets or JSP files within an application when the application starts.Default is create MBeans.
Override class reloading settings for web and EJB modules?

Specifies whether the product run time detects changes to application classes when the application is running. If yes, then on such changes application is stopped and restarted to reload updated classes.
Reload interval in seconds
Specifies the number of seconds to scan the application's file system for updated files.Default is 3 seconds.
Deploy web services?
Specifies whether to deploy web services.Default is NO.
Validate resource references

Specifies whether websphere examines the application references specified during application installation or updating and, if validation is enabled, warns you of incorrect references or fails the operation.
Process embedded configuration?
Specifies whether the embedded configuration should be processed. An embedded configuration consists of files such as resource.xml, variables.xml, and deployment.xml.
File permission
Specifies access permissions for application binaries.Valid values are Allow all files to be read but not written to,Allow executables to execute,Allow HTML and image files to be read by everyone
Customized file permission
Provide custom file permissions if not listed in File permissions drop down.
Businesslevel application name

Specifies whether websphere creates a new businesslevel application with the enterprise application that you are installing or makes the enterprise application a composition unit of an existing businesslevel application.The default is to create a new businesslevel application
Allow EJB reference targets to resolve automatically
Specifies whether the product assigns default JNDI values for or automatically resolves incomplete EJB reference targets.
Deploy client modules
Select if the file to deploy has one or more client modules and want to configure environment entries for the client modules.Default is do not enable Client Module
Client deployment mode

Specifies whether to deploy client modules to an isolated deployment target (Isolated), a federated node of a deployment manager (Federated), or an application server (Server Deployed).Default is Isolated
Validate schema
Specifies whether to validate the deployment descriptors against published Java EE deployment descriptor schemas.
Map modules to servers

Specify deployment targets where you want to install the modules that are contained in your application. Modules can be installed on the same deployment target or dispersed among several deployment targets.Give input in format [ "Module1Name" Module1URL server1][ "Module2Name" Module2URL server2 ] E.g.[ "Increment EJB module" Increment.jar,META-INF/ejb-jar.xml WebSphere:cell=Cell01,node=Node01,server=singleServer ]
Additional deployment parameters
Specify any additional options for AdminApp.Install object in case not listed in this input form.

div.p: To deploy an enterprise application, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
enterprise application is deployed successfully:

In the DeployEnterpriseApp/b> step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.

This procedure deploys the OSGi application.It optionally configures external OSGi bundle library if the application to be deployed reference bundles that are stored in an external bundle repository. This procedure can also add the bundles to internal bundle repository, if required..

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Want to add external bundle repository?

If your OSGi applications reference bundles that are stored in an external bundle repository, you must configure a link (name and URL) to the repository so that the provisioner can retrieve the bundles when required.
External Bundle Repository Name
Name of the external bundle repository to configure.
External Bundle Repository URL
URL of the external bundle repository to configure.
List of bundles to add to local repository

Comma separated list of bundles to add to internal bundle repository.E.g. C:/installableApps/com.ibm.samples.websphere.osgi.logging.api.jar,C:/installableApps/com.ibm.samples.websphere.osgi.logging.impl.jar
EBA file Path
Absolute path of the OSGi application to deploy. i.e: '/path/to/blog.eba' or 'c:/mydir/blog.eba'.
Application Name
>Name to be given to newly deployed OSGi application.
Target Deployment Unit
Deployment Unit on which to deploy the OSGi application. For e.g cluster=cluster1 or node=node01,server=server1

div.p: To deploy an OSGi application, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
OSGi application is deployed successfully:

In the DeployOSGi step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure creates mail provider with a protocol provider, a mail session and a custom property in the specified scope.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Scope
Specifies the scope in which the mail provider supports installed mail applications.
Mail Provider Name
Specifies the name to be given to the new mail provider .
Mail Provider Description
Specifies the mail provider description.
Isolate this mail provider?

Specifies that this mail provider will be loaded in its own class loader. This allows the application server to load different versions or implementations of the same mail provider in the same Java Virtual Machine. Give each version or implementation of the mail provider a unique class path in following (Mail provider classpath) field that is appropriate for that version or implementation.
Mail Provider Classpath
Specifies the class path to a Java archive (JAR) file that contains the implementation classes for this mail provider.
Custom Property Name
>Specifies the name of custom property to create.
Custom Property Value
Specifies the value to associate with this custom property of the resource.
Protocol Provider Name
Specifies the name to be given to the new protocol provider .
Protocol Provider Class Name
Specifies the implementation class of this protocol provider.
Protocol Provider Type
Specifies the type of protocol provider. Valid options are STORE(for incoming protocol provider) or TRANSPORT(for outgoing protocol provider).
Mail Session Name
Specifies the administrative name of the JavaMail session object.
Mail Session JNDI Name
Specifies the Java Naming and Directory Interface (JNDI) name for the resource, including any naming subcontexts.
Category
Optional string to use while classifying or grouping the resources.
Enable Debug Mode?
Select to print the interaction between mail application and mail server as well as the properties of this mail session to System.Out.log file.
Mail Session Description
Specifies optional description for mail session.
Incoming Mail Server
Specifies the host name server that is accessed when receiving mail.
Incoming Mail Server Port
Specifies the port of the server that is accessed when receiving mail..
Incoming Mail Server Credentials
Specifies the credential for the mail account when the incoming mail server requires authentication.
Outgoing Mail Server
Specifies the host name of server that is accessed when sending mail.
Outgoing Mail Server Port
Specifies the port of the server that is accessed when sending mail.
Outgoing Mail Server Credential
Specifies the user of the mail account when the outgoing mail server requires authentication.
Enable Strict Internet Address Parsing?
Specifies whether the recipient addresses must be parsed in strict compliance with RFC 822.

div.p: To create a new mail provider along with protocol provider and mail session, do these steps:

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
OSGi application is deployed successfully:

In the CreateEndToEndMailProvider step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.
This procedure publishes WSDL files in each web services-enabled module to the file system location.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Commands
Commands to be entered to wsadmin. Use one command per line.
Java Parameters
Java options to be passed to wsadmin, separate them using semicolons (;).
Classpath

Jars to be passed to the wsadmin classpath. It is a string containing paths (semicolon-separated) the required JARs to execute wsadmin in a particular job. i.e: 'c:/MyDir/Myjar.jar;d:/yourdir/yourdir.jar' or '/MyDir/Myjar.jar;/yourdir/yourdir.jar'.
Application Name
Name of the application of which to publish the WSDL file. i.e: 'webapp'.
Location to publish WSDL file
Path on file system where to store the published WSDL files. i.e: 'webapp'.
SOAP address prefixes

Give SOAP address prefix in format "{{module {{binding partial-url}}}}" to customize the WSDL SOAP address for each module.. i.e: '{ {AddressBookJ2WB.war {{http http://localhost:9080}}} {StockQuote.jar {{http https://localhost:9443}}} }'.
Additional Commands
Additional commands to be entered for wsadmin.
Target Deployment Unit
Deployment Unit on which to deploy the OSGi application. For e.g cluster=cluster1 or node=node01,server=server1

div.p: To publish WSDL files, do these steps:
This procedure updates already deployed application in units of files,modules or entire application.

tr.td: Configuration Name
The name of the configuration to use. ElectricCommander gets the URL, port, and credentials from this configuration.
Wsadmin Absolute Path
Path to wsadmin. If the location of wsadmin is in the PATH environment variable, then just the script name can be specified omitting its full path. E.g. /path/to/wsadmin.sh or wsadmin.bat.
Connection Type
Specifies to type of connection to use to connect to the application server that you want to administer. The valid choices are SOAP, RMI, and NONE. Default is SOAP.
Application Name
Name of the web application to be updated. i.e: 'webapp'.
Content Type

Specifies to type of content to update. Use File option for updating a single file, Partial Application option for updating application partially, Module option to add/update a module to the deployed application, Application option for updating the entire deployed application.
Operation

Specifies to type of operation to perform as part of update procedure. Use Add option to add new content, Update option to update existing content, AddUpdate option to add content and to replace if already exist, Delete option to remove existing content respectively.
Content

Specifies the file that contains the content that you want to update. For example, depending on the content type, the file could be an EAR file, a module, a partial zip, or a single file.Not required for Delete operation.
Content URI

The relative path beginning with the installed application archive file to the file to be replaced or added. For example, if the file is located at com/company/greeting.class in module hello.jar, specify hello.jar/com/company/greeting.class for the relative path
Is the application deployed on cluster?
Select this checkbox if the application to be updated is deployed on cluster.
Cluster Name
Name of the cluster on which application is deployed.
Server Name
Name of the server on which application is deployed.
Additional Parameters
Additional parameters to pass while updating entire application or module/s, if required. For e.g. -nodeployejb, -BindJndiForEJBNonMessageBinding etc.

After the job runs, you can view the results, including the following job details, which show that
WSDL files are published successfully:

In the UpdateApp step, click the Log icon
to see the diagnostic information. The output is similar to
the following diagnostic
report.

ul.li: Starting in EC-WebSphere 2.0.6, add information about the changes in the plugin release, including details about resolved issues, changed behaviour and functionality, and new features, to this document. (NMB-18829)
Restructured the information in this document.
Fixed the DeployApp procedure to not include the password in the log file.
Fixed the problem about attaching credentials in the CheckApp procedure.
Fixed the problem where the wsadmin password appeared when you view job step log files and property information.
Fixed instructions to create WebSphere plugin configurations.
Fixed instructions to access plugins in ElectricCommander.

div.h1: What's New for Previous EC-WebSphere Releases

ul.li: Added support for Websphere Network deployment edition v8.5.
Added support for cluster setup viz Create cluster, Add application servers to it,Deploy application on a cluster, remove cluster members and delete the specified cluster.
Added support for deploying java enterprise applications (EARs) in addition to web archives (WARs).
Added support for update of already deployed application.
Added support for deploying OSGi applications and configuration of external and internal bundle repositories.
Added support for configuration of session management for deployed application.
Added support for setting up EJB container properties for better memory consumption and statefull session bean failover feature.
Added support for JavaMail session.
Fix minor bugs.
Add four new procedures: CreateDatasources, DeleteDatasources, CreateJDBCProviders, and DeleteJDBCProviders.
Fix minor bugs.
Change the procedure names in the step picker section.
Make improvements to the help document.
Use the new Parameter Form XML.

Add a link directly to the new help
document.
Use the new help page format.
Add new parameter panels for each procedure.
Add the CheckPageStatus procedure.

Remove the CURL dependency from the
CheckServerStatus procedure.
Fix minor bugs.

The procedures now have only one step using ec-perl
to execute the necessary commands.
Fix a minor bug on the Configuration List page.

Add the StartApp, StopApp, DeployApp, and
UndeployApp procedures.

Jython commands can now be entered manually in the
RunCustomJob procedure.

The absolute path of executable files now requires the path and
filename with an extension.
Add the RunCustomJob procedure.

div.p: Contacting Technical Support:
Before you contact our technical support staff, have the following information available.

ol.li: Your name, title, company name, phone number, fax number, and email address

div.p: Hours: 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM PST (Monday-Friday, except Holidays)
Phone: 408-419-4300, Option #2
Email: support@electric-cloud.com
